description.narrative: Objective Strengthen the management of Togoâ€™s protected area system to improve its contribution to biodiversity conservation by demonstrating effective approaches to PA rehabilitation and management.
1. Coverage of the National Protected Area System of Togo

comment.narrative:
A dysfunctional PA Estate: 793,000 ha in 83 sites, many of which serve no conservation purpose and are currently a burden for the PA system. The status for the 10 priority sites is described in PRODOC Table 1. These are: 1. Fazao-Malfakassa/AniÃ©
2. Abdoulaye
3. Oti-KÃ©ran / Oti-Mandouri Complex
4. Togodo South/North
5. BayÃ©mÃ©
6. Amou-Mono/
7. Tchilla-Monota
8. AlÃ©djo
9. Lionsâ€™ Den
10. AssÃ©vÃ© and GodjinmÃ©

A rationalized PA estate: 578,250 ha (with ~ 456,883 ha in 10 priority PA)
Proposed mid-term target:
Completing the reclassification process for 10 priority sites sites and having accurate maps on Google Earth (to visualise land use patterns) for the remainder sites is an adequate project target by mid-term.
[Note on logframe revision 2013: The proposed mid-term target is accepted by the RTA]

The mid-term target is not reached but well underway.
Pursuing the objective of securing 578,250 ha, the project has worked in 2014 to get the support of local populations and other interested parties and implement partial demarcation of the PA Oti-Mandouri. Thus, 36% of this PA perimeters have been secured. These operations should continue and be completed in 2015. Quoting from the MTR:
" Project interventions for requalification of APs system have focused so far on 4 of the 10 priority APs identified in the draft document of AP added during the project. Consensual delimitation and demarcation of transactions with community participation helped secure over 129 000 ha area for the following APs:
Fazao-Malfakassa (˜100 000 ha, 52% approx.)
Aledjo (approx 1. 000 ha)
Balam (approx. 5000 ha) and Oti-Keran (42 milestones on about 30 km, some limits are still confined in the Prefecture of Keran and ten km limit in the prefecture of Oti ). Togodo South / North and Abdoulaye have been delineated and bounded by DERF with other supports. OKM for the complex, this step is a prerequisite for the development and implementation of protected areas management tools, and the low level of progress affects other achievements. This delay is linked to difficult access due to the resistance of the people who occupy or use land within the APs. The precise geographical coordinates of all terminals located around the APs are available for Fazao-Malfakassa, Alédjo, Balam and Oti-Keran. Requalification Files are being prepared for Abdoulaye Togodo North / South Fazao-Malfakassa, Alédjo and Balam and OKM.
The digitization of the polygons of the 10 priority APs has been completed for the establishment of the geographic database." The MTR notes: "The mid-term target is not reached but well underway . The obstacles that have slowed consensual delineation activities have been removed and most of the local communities are willing to adhere to the objectives of the project to the extent that the minimum conditions for their subsistence are provided (improvement of soil productivity and access water) , and where concrete achievements attest to the willingness of the State to improve the management of protected areas for the benefit of local residents." A change to the indicator formulation for clarity is provided by the MTR.

description.narrative: 2. Estimated permanent and temporary populations of Elephants in Togo are increasing

comment.narrative: ~ 70 permanent (estimation 2010)
At least 90 permanent (return of the ~20 (1990) elephants in Oti-KÃ©ran)

Limited progress towards target. There were no formal agreements between the authorities in charge of PAs and the local communities but the works to establish the requalification records have continued during 2014. Consensual demarcation of protected areas of OKM complex that could not be completed because of resistance shown by communities motivated by resentment toward the previous mode PAs management and that were influenced by influential people from the area intervention. This consequently delays all operations leading to the participatory development of co-management agreements, the management plan including zoning, associated regulations and the business plan. To reduce this barrier, the project, with the support of the Minister of the Environment, held meetings with executives and opinion leaders, and with the support of the prefects, with local communities to raise awareness on profits related to PA. An action plan to achieve consensual boundaries of OKM complex was presented to the parties concerned to promote their adherence to interventions in the field. Thus, during the same period, partial demarcation of the PA Oti-Mandouri has established a document signed by all the different actors (village chiefs, presidents of AVGAPs and representatives of the residents close to the protected area, the CVD presidents. The development of an Information Action Plan - Education-Communication will generate general support for PAs and biodiversity conservation. The MTR notes: "This indicator is not an outcome indicator and should not be at this level. The management tools are products and their preparation is not an effect . It would be more appropriate to use an indicator of the effect of the application of these management tools."

description.narrative: 3. PA in the Savannah biome of the OKM complex have zoning, management and business plans which include biodiversity conservation and riparian communities needs and are enforced

comment.narrative: PA: 0 Agreements DFC local communities (represented by 10 AVGAPs and 4 UAVGAPs), concerning co-management and natural resource use in PAs : 0
PA: 2 Agreements DFC local communities (represented by 10 AVGAPs and 4 UAVGAPs), concerning co-management and natural resource use in PAs : â‰¥ 14

There were no formal agreements between the authorities in charge of PAs and the local communities but the works to establish the requalification records have continued during 2014. Consensual demarcation of protected areas of OKM complex that could not be completed because of resistance shown by communities motivated by resentment toward the previous mode PAs management and that were influenced by influential people from the area intervention. This consequently delays all operations leading to the participatory development of co-management agreements, the management plan including zoning, associated regulations and the business plan. To reduce this barrier, the project, with the support of the Minister of the Environment, held meetings with executives and opinion leaders, and with the support of the prefects, with local communities to raise awareness on profits related to PA. An action plan to achieve consensual boundaries of OKM complex was presented to the parties concerned to promote their adherence to interventions in the field. Thus, during the same period, partial demarcation of the PA Oti-Mandouri has established a document signed by all the different actors (village chiefs, presidents of AVGAPs and representatives of the residents close to the protected area, the CVD presidents. The development of an Information Action Plan - Education-Communication will generate general support for PAs and biodiversity conservation

description.narrative: Outcome 1) Improved policy, legal and institutional framework for PA estate covering approximately 578,000 hectares.
4. Improved competence levels and standards of the institution responsible for PA, measured by increased scores of the Capacity Development Scorecard:

comment.narrative: See PRODOC Annex 4 for a complete baseline reference Total: 35 /out of 96

Scores, expressed in absolute terms, increase by at least 20%
Total: 42/out of 96

Target achieved as validated by the MTR. Policy Development
systemic 5/6
institutional 1/3 Implementation
systemic 7/9
institutional 17/27
individual 5/12 Commitment consensus
systemic 3/6
institutional 3/6
individual 2/3 Information and knowledge
systemic 2/3
institutional 2/3
individual 2/3 Monitoring
Systemic 2/6
institutional 3/6
individual 1/3 TOTAL: 55/96 The project reports:
The development of PAs Management Capacity for the branch staff in charge of PAs and other stakeholders include - 30 people trained in anti-poaching and - 60 people trained in protected area management interfaces - peripheries (including conflict management around PAs), 30 people trained in management and participatory monitoring - 30 people were equipped on features and management of protected areas and peripheries, the protected areas monitoring strategy and self-organization for participatory monitoring. This prelude to the establishment and operationalization of a system of participatory management and monitoring of complex OKM. - Organization of a study tour with 20 people conducted in Benin The MTR reports:
" The development APs in management capacity for the staff of the Directorate in charge of APs and other stakeholders include
- 27 decision makers have received training on the use of the METT tool by the regional office of IUCN
- 45 managers trained in co-management of APs
- Twenty executives capable of driving the process of delimitation and demarcation of consensual APs with neighboring communities ( negotiation skills and GPS use) ;
- Forty executives trained in collection techniques and data analysis of the walking wildlife inventory and processing of census data;
- Training of members of AVGAP ( PA management , co-management , support of AVGAP and UAVGAP )" The MTR notes:
" Scrutiny on the results of the implementation of the tracking tool of management efficiency APs (METT) applied to the APs OKM complex revealed that the form had not been filled consistently, this which calls into question the effectiveness of specific training in the use of this tool. Given the special issues associated with APs and local communities in Togo, it is essential that managers of protected areas have the tools and capacity in social mobilization and communication.
The overall improvement observed using the Scorecard on capacity development than the intended target at the end of the project. It is mainly related to the improvement of institutional and individual capacities to implement policies, legislation, strategies and programs.
The current legal framework (Articles 81-86 LCE- and Forestry Code) include provisions on the creation of protected areas or areas but does not define the requirements for their creation and management, nor foresee the modalities of their management and benefit sharing."

description.narrative: 5. Improved financial sustainability of PA management agency, measured by increased scores of the Financial Sustainability Scorecard broken down by 4 sub-indicators

comment.narrative:
Scorecard Component 1) Legal and regulatory framework
17.9% (baseline was 14 out of 82)
Scorecard Component 2) Business planning
0% (baseline was 0 out of 67)
Scorecard Component3) Tools for revenue generation 7% (baseline was 4 out of 57)
[5a] Total 8.7% (baseline was 18 out of 206)
Other scorecard indicators to be monitored at the PA system's level are: [5b]
Under Finances available, Item 5)
Total finances available to the PA system: $200K p.a. in 2009. [5c]
Costs and Financing Needs, Items 2A and 2B)
Estimation of financing needs for basic and optimal management: ranging between $14M and $20M p.a. in 2009 for 10 priority sites, though with no explanations on the figure.
[5d]
Financing Gap, Items 2 and 3) Annual financing gap for basic and optimal management: ranging between $13.8M and $19.8M p.a. in 2009. [NOTE ON LOGFRAME 2014: slight correction in the numbering made for the sake of clarity and correct correspondence.]

[5a] Total score by end of project, expressed in percentage terms, increases to at least 18%
[5b] at least $2M by project end.
[5c] a realistic and attainable figure is proposed for the 10 priority sites and for the entire PA system (e.g. based on costs per hectares for specific sub-systems), and with explanatory notes provided, covering both for basic and optimal management scenarios.
[5d] gap for basic management: below $3M p.a. by project end.

Target achieved. Results of the dashboard on the financing of the APs system completed in 2014 : Legal and regulatory framework : 33% ( 32/96 )
Planning of activities : 2% ( 1/54 )
Revenue generation tools : 8% ( 6/71 )
Total: 17.6% ( 39/221 ) The observed overall improvement has reached the intended target at the end of the project. It is mainly due to an improvement in legal, regulatory and institutional. The MTR notes:
"International technical assistance is provided in the project for a study to propose a funding strategy to mobilize various sources dedicated to the management of the APs Togo system."

description.narrative:
Outcome 2)
Effective management of the OKM PA Complex (with 179,000 ha of protected land surface) counters threats to biodiversity from poaching, uncontrolled fire and grazing
6. Legal status of re-demarcated PAs of the OKM Complex

comment.narrative:
2 re-demarcated PAs officially gazetted end of 2nd project year (i.e. 2015)
[Note on logframe revision 2013: The year for the proposed mid-term target should be 2015.]

Steady progress towards target. The reaffirmation of the will of the government that has shown its determination to implement the forest policy in Togo through the circular note No. 261 / PM / SGG / 2015 of 28 April 2015 addressed to the Honourable Members to the National Assembly, to Ministers and Secretaries of State should reduce the interference of some political men in PA management especially in the complex OKM. A review of the legal framework of PAs and a proposal for an improved framework and adapted to the context of decentralization were conducted in parallel with the evaluation of institutional and human framework that will provide Togo with an action plan strengthening human and material capacities, necessary tool for planning the management of PAs. To ensure that all local stakeholders at the OKM complex effectively participate in major decisions about AP and find local conflict management solutions, a Local Management Committee (GLC) was established and all organs installed during a Constitutive General Assembly. But overall, the legal position of the PA OKM Complex is improving rather slowly. The initiation of actions to improve the legal, regulatory and institutional by the project (review of the legal and institutional framework, setting up a local management committee of the complex OKM, etc.) and supported by the DRF 2014 should help to improve the legal position of OKM complex. The MTR notes:
" Over 50 dossiers of consensual demarcation were signed with local residents in order to complete requalification records.
A review of the legal framework for APs analyzed the sorting options , decommissioning and retraining and proposed an improved framework adapted to the context of decentralization.
One study evaluated the feasibility of the creation and operation of a regional structure that would be responsible for coordinating the management of APs in the OKM complex ensuring the participation of stakeholders , including AVGAP and UAVGAP , major decisions Management."

description.narrative: 7. Improved PA management effectiveness at the two PA sites (Oti-KÃ©ran, Oti Mandouri) of the OKM complex for general management and business planning, as measured by increases in the METT scores

comment.narrative: Scores 2010: Oti-KÃ©ran: 26.5 % Oti Mandouri: 15.7 %

Target achieved. The project reports: The effectiveness of PA management on both AP sites (Oti-Keran, Oti Mandouri) of OKM Complex for the general management plan and activities, measured by METT scores yielded:
35% for the AP Oti-Keran
34% for Oti-Mandouri in 2014. Although the evaluation of the scores vary greatly dependent on the actors who respond, if the actors are not the same it calls into question the validity of comparisons over time, however there is a net improvement in these scores moving from 26.5% (baseline) to 35% in 2014 for the AP Oti-Keran reaching the end of project target. This target is also widely exceeded regarding the management of the PA Oti-Mandouri from 15.7% (baseline) to 34% in 2014 against a target project completion 27.4%. This progress is partly explained by awareness campaigns, AVGAP revitalizing and strengthening the capacities of stakeholders involved in the management of this complex for monitoring of the AP and anti-poaching. In addition to these trainings, brigade Naboulgou has two motorcycles, four buildings (dormitories) of this brigade are being rehabilitated and a brigade is under construction in Borgou. The latter benefited from the support of a significant part of village community by granting a plot of 2 ha in Borgou for the construction of this station. The MTR reports:
“The assessment of the effectiveness of PA management Oti - Keran (a 25% b 35% ) , Oti - Mandouri (a 22% , b: 34%), Abdoulaye , Fazao Malfakassa (59%) , Balam ( 23%) and Alédjo ( 33%). The effectiveness of PA management of OKM complex was assessed in April 2014 with the METT assessment tool. This assessment was reviewed during the mid -term with the project team and , having found gaps in responses , scores and comments were fully revised , which resulted in an overall assessment significantly APs for high - Oti Oti - Keran and Mandouri (34 % and 35 % instead of 22% and 25%) , reaching the intended target at the end of the project.”

The effectiveness of PA management on both AP sites (Oti-Keran, Oti Mandouri) of OKM Complex for the general management plan and activities, measured by METT scores returned 35% for the AP Oti-Keran and 34% for Oti-Mandouri in 2014. Although the evaluation of the scores vary greatly dependent on the actors who respond, if the actors are not the same it calls into question the validity of comparisons over time, however there is a net improvement in these scores moving from 26.5% (baseline) to 35% in 2014 for the AP Oti-Keran reaching the end of project target. This target is also widely exceeded regarding the management of the PA Oti-Mandouri from 15.7% (baseline) to 34% in 2014 against a target project completion 27.4%. This progress is partly explained by awareness campaigns, AVGAP revitalizing and strengthening the capacities of stakeholders involved in the management of this complex for monitoring of the AP and anti-poaching.
In addition to these trainings, brigade Naboulgou has two motorcycles, four buildings (dormitories) of this brigade are being rehabilitated and a brigade is under construction in Borgou. The latter benefited from the support of a significant part of village community by granting a plot of 2 ha in Borgou for the construction of this station.

description.narrative: 8. Ecosystem and habitat regeneration in the two OKM complex PA

comment.narrative: Oti-KÃ©ran: 18% of the surface of the core protection zone occupied by agriculture Oti-Mandouri: 16% of the surface of the core protection zone occupied by agriculture OKM complex: ~16.700 people living in 54 villages inside the complex

â‰¥ 50% reduced habitat conversion: Oti-KÃ©ran: â‰¤ 9% of the surface of the core protection zone occupied by agriculture Oti-Mandouri: â‰¤ 8% of the surface of the core protection zone occupied by agriculture Reduced human pressure in the OKM complex: â‰¤ 10,000 people living in 20 villages inside the complex

Not possible to inform indicator. The project reports:
In 2014, the regeneration of ecosystems and habitats in both protected areas OKM Complex has not been measured although the land cover map for all OKM complex was developed from the processing of satellite images Landsat 8. But as was also pointed out the mid-term, with the sharp increase of human occupation within the PA, it seems unrealistic to achieve reduction of the cultivated area in half by the end of the Project especially considering that compensation could be granted for communities to voluntarily leave the PA. It is considered an alternative measure for the reduction of pressure by reducing the number of people living in the 54 communities installed in the grip of complex. The land use map for the whole OKM complex should be improved through timely and more accurate data using the new digital topographic map of Togo and high resolution RapidEye satellite image acquired in 2013 by the Ministry. Quoting the MTR:
" In support of the surrounding communities , the project
- Designed in new water points on the periphery of the OKM AP complex with the construction of two pump wells powered by solar energy and N'Gambi Natiponi ;
- Started the process of rehabilitation of wells and former earth dams and rainwater retention reservoirs and streams during the rainy season,
- Offered training on making compost whose adoption by farmers is limited due to supply constraints straw and water." Furthermore, the MTR made several recommendations about changing this indicator completely.

description.narrative:
DROPPED INDICATOR:
This indicator is repeated and it proposed dropped.
[was #9.] PA in the Savannah biome of the OKM complex have zoning, management and business plans which include biodiversity conservation and riparian communities needs and are enforced]
[Note on logframe revision 2013: Indicator dropped and this is accepted by the RTA]

comment.narrative:
DROPPED INDICATOR:
This indicator is repeated and it proposed dropped.
[PA: 0
Agreements DFC -local communities (represented by 10 AVGAPs and 4 UAVGAPs), concerning co-management and natural resource use in PAs : 0]
[Note on logframe revision 2013: Indicator dropped and this is accepted by the RTA]

DROPPED INDICATOR:
This indicator is repeated and it proposed dropped.
[PA: 2
Agreements DFC local communities (represented by 10 AVGAPs and 4 UAVGAPs), concerning co-management and natural resource use in PAs : â‰¥ 14]
[Note on logframe revision 2013: Indicator dropped and this is accepted by the RTA]

description.narrative: 9. Income generation from new PA and biodiversity value chains for local communities (ecotourism, benefit sharing, small game farming, local job creation etc.) [re-numbered]

comment.narrative: To be identified during management and business plan elaboration for each zone

Not possible to inform indicator. - New Value Chains revenue generation from PA and biodiversity to local communities (ecotourism, profit sharing, small game breeding, creation of local jobs, etc.) started in 2014 around the complex OKM . In supporting the development of sustainable livelihoods helping to reduce pressure on resources, the project has funded about 10 AGR benefiting communities located on the periphery of the complex PA OKM (beekeeping, shea butter production) worth almost 65 million CFA francs. The project financed 10 AGR benefiting communities located on the periphery of the complex PAs OKM (beekeeping, shea butter production) worth more than $ 125 000. - The materialization of production materials provided direct resources to the local population in the form of local workforce of over 7,000 and over $ 5,000 dollars in purchasing the construction equipment in Borgou. Over a hundred people in local communities, of which 30% are women, have benefited from these contributions. MTR notes and also makes suggestions to chaning the indicator.
"In supporting the development of sustainable livelihoods contributing to reduce pressure on resources,
- The project has funded about 10 AGR benefiting communities located on the outskirts of the APs OKM complex ( beekeeping, shea butter production )
- The work of materialization of the limits of APs (manufacture of terminals ) have brought revenues of nearly five million CFA francs a month in a hundred people in local communities , including 25 % women , but the income is not unsustainable."

description.narrative:
10. Critical habitats and key natural resources for elephant migration at regional level (OKM - WAP) are identified and priority threats addressed, including through WAPOK-wide cooperation among the WAPOK countries
[Note on logframe revision2013: The indicator has now an improve and clearer formulation and it is accepted by the RTA] [re-numbered]

comment.narrative:
Some useful maps are contained in PRODOC Annex 9. Atlas of the project region. These are not sufficiently detailed to prioritise action on critical habitats, elephant migration
[Note on logframe revision 2013: The indicator has now an improve and clearer formulation and it is accepted by the RTA]

By mid-term, the project would have identified:
(a) key habitats for elephant migration across the WAPOK Complex involving the OKM Sub-Complex
(b) nevralgic points for elephant poaching across the WAPOK Complex involving the OKM Sub-Complex
(c) At least 3 priority activities (including urgent and costed actions) for addressing the threats of elephant poaching across the WAPOK Complex involving the OKM Sub-Complex and requiring cross-border cooperation among the WAPOK countries.
[Note on logframe revision 2013: The indicator has now an improve and clearer formulation and it is accepted by the RTA â€˜ 2014 renumbered to a, b, c.]

Not possible to fully inform indicator. But MTR notes:
" To define a migration corridor for wildlife between the OKM complex ( Togo ) and W -Arly - Pendjari ( Benin - Burkina Faso - Niger ) and to improve ecological connectivity , the project has the participation of local authorities ( 3 prefects of the prefectures, 2 canton chiefs , presidents UAVGAP 2 , 2 and 2 NGO representatives regional Directors of the environment) to find solutions to problems encountered in the implementation of field activities at the forum players WAPO in Ouagadougou (Burkina Faso ) . The participation of these representatives of Togo should contribute to the harmonization of management / conservation measures within the OKM complex with the measures in place in the WAP . To improve the capacity of national frameworks for PA management and facilitate the integration of Togo to regional initiatives , national cadres participated in planning meetings in Benin and Burkina Faso ."

description.narrative: 11. Number of PIT (integrated land use plans), which integrate biodiversity conservation and elephant migration needs [re-numbered]

comment.narrative: At least 4. In the Savannes Region, covering 2 Prefectures: (1) Kpendjal; (2) Oti. In the Kara Region, covering one Prefecture: (3) KÃ©ran [Note on logframe revision2013: The indicator has now a defined target and it is accepted by the RTA]

Approaching target at 75%. MTR notes:
"3 territorial integration plans have been developed by the National Decentralized Actions Programme for Environmental Management ( PNADE - closed in 2013) for the three prefectures within the complex APs OKM"

description.narrative: Togo's self-assessment for the preparation of the third national Communication to hte UNFCCC
Projet d'élaboration de la 3e communication nationale
independent political entity
DEVELOPPEMENT EFFECTIVENESS
Development effectiveness
Strengthening National and Decentralized Management for Global Environmental Benefits
PIMS 4460_CCCD Togo-Strengthen
Energy - policy, planning and administration
To strengthen national and decentralized management to produce global environmental benefits

comment.narrative:
* Capacity of the main stakeholders is low and dispersed over many organisations;
* Budgets for environmental initiatives in Togo remain low due to ignorance of environmental impacts of human interventions;

* 50% of stakeholders have benefitted from capacity building activity at the systemic, organizational, and individual level for better use of the technical skills and technology transfer for national and decentralized management to produce global environmental benefits (e.g. training and workshops);
* an updated NSSD has been adopted as overarching coordinating strategy;
* long-term and continued availability of finances to ensure the stability of both central and local government structures and decision-making mechanisms, such as the CNDD and CNCC
* Project has contributed to a significant rise in the elaboration and financing of CBO environmental projects (40%) in the intervention zones (8 prefectures).
* Togo will be able to achieve global environmental benefits at a lower transactional cost as well as being able to response faster and more appropriately to local conservation needs.
* reported better access at the sub-regional level to best practices and best available knowledge, including innovative research,
* key stakeholders report improved coordination, collaboration, and delegation of responsibilities among key agencies and other important organizations

The targeted stakeholders include CNDD, FNE, CNCC, ANGE and the 10 prefectures. Regarding this, technical decision-making tools, as detailed in the paragraph below, have been produced to the government relating to FNE, CNDD and CNCC. Local actors have been trained and a large public sensitized in the 10 prefectures. This performance makes estimate the progress enough encouraging.
The ongoing survey for assessing the public awareness level on Rio Conventions is expected to provide with data enabling a better appreciation of the progress in capacity building at the systemic, organizational, and individual level. As the government is working on the sustainable development goals which combines millennium development goals (MDG) and sustainable development, the suitable orientation to given to the National Sustainable Development Strategy depends on the government new approach results. Furthermore, based on the favorable opinion of a panel of experts who reviewed the CNDD, a couple of required tools for the operationalization of CNCC, CNDD and its branches, has been produced and given to government. These tools include a technical report on the CNDD operationalization and the ToR for the Permanent Secretary recruitment. Once the Permanent Secretary of CNDD is appointed, a main objective would be achieved. (See rating comments). A guide for developing prefecture territorial integration plan for sustainable development (PIT-DD) has been elaborated and vulgarized. The capacity of 364 community representatives from 10 prefectures has been strengthened on Rio conventions. Based on this, the progress toward the objectives achievement can be deemed encouraging. Foundations for expected changes from the last 3 development objectives are laid. But a relevant report on their indicators depends on the further progress in the prior ones reported above.

description.narrative: Key national institutions will have the necessary absorptive capacities to manage their environment and natural resources in a way that meets their sustainable development priorities while at the same time delivers global environmental benefits.

* the project has involved large numbers of stakeholder representatives in understanding, developing, and testing best practices for meeting global environmental obligations through decentralized environmental governance;
* Ministry in charge of Environment, CNDD, ANGE, FNE and the CNCC (as representative of the convention secretariats) have created a conducive environment for their decentralized implementation;

comment.narrative:
* The institutional analysis of the Sustainable Development National Commission (CNDD) is realized and ToR for the recruitement of its Permanent Secretary have been elaborated and submitted to the government. These are are decision-making tools for a quick operationalization of the CNDD. So, the achievement level of this indicator can be estimated to 50%. * The national agency for environmental management (ANGE) has its institutional analysis completed with a financial support of European Union. The implementation of some activities is about to start with the project ressources. The purpose is to strengthen ANGE to better assist local authorities. So, the achievement level of this output can be estimated to 100%.
* Institutional analysis of the Sustainable Development National Commission (CNDD) is realized and ToR for the recruitement of its Permanent Secretary have been elaborated and submitted to the government. These are are decision-making tools for a quick operationalization of the CNDD. So, the achievement level of this indicator can be estimated to 50%. * The national agency for environmental management (ANGE) has its institutional analysis completed with a financial support of European Union. The implementation of some activities is about to start with the project ressources. The purpose is to strengthen ANGE to better assist local authorities. So, the achievement level of this output can be estimated to 100%. * The Rio conventions’ national committees have been analysed in conjunction with the CNDD by laying emphasis on the climate change national committee (CNCC). The evolvement of that indicator depends on the way CNDD issues will be reoriented by the government. So, the achievement level of this indicator can be estimated to 50%. * The feasibility study of the National Fund for Environment (FNE) has been updated. Measures for a quick operationalization have been suggested by a panel to the government. As soon as the FNE executive director will be recruited, the remaining outputs will follow. The achievement level of this indicator can be estimated to 50%. As the new government appointed after the 2015 election already takes steps relating to the FNE, it is hopeful to have this indicator fully completed probably during the next PIR period. * The Rio conventions committees national committes have been analysedin conjunction with the CNDD by focusing on the climate change national committee (CNCC). The achievement level of this indicator can be estimated to 50%.

description.narrative: The capacities of eight (8) prefectures will have been strengthened to better govern their natural resources within their policy and planning frameworks of sustainable development.

comment.narrative: * The issue of prefectures’ mandates revisions has been examined during the institutional analysis of the CNDD. It is pointed out that the prefectures’ mandates revisions should depend on the operationalization of the CNDD and its local branches. Since the CNDD process is estimated at 50%, the progress towards this indicator remains low. * 10 reports assessing the capacities of the of pilot prefectures to implement the Rio conventions have been validated. It is pointed out that there are needs for environmental information, sensitization and training regarding the Rio Conventions. * 364 (13 women) CPDD and cantonal development committee (CCD) members of the 10 prefectures have been trained. Each of them received a teaching kit containing 3 modules on Rio conventions. This performance can be estimated at 90%. If the cantons’ trained leaders return the acquired knowledge as promised, then, at least 20 members of the Cantonal Development Committees (CCD) would also be reached. Hence, about 2,800 community actors could be informed on Rio convention.

description.narrative: Enhanced awareness and long-term commitment to decentralized governance of the global environment

comment.narrative:
* decision makers at national level are ignorant of the environmental problems at the local level;
* communities are not aware of the severity of the environmental problems in their locality;

* The project's inception meeting was held in 18, April 2014 with the attendance of representatives of the 10 pilot prefectures, NGOs involved in environmental management, UNDP and officials. * Learning lessons from the poor performance of the set of 50 environmental journalists trained under the PNADE programme in 2013, an innovating initiative has been experienced, consisting on strengthening the capacities of 10 community-based radios broadcasting in the pilot prefectures. 10 journalists in charge of environmental programmes have been trained. Thousands of listeners probably would be informed on climate change, biodiversity and desertification issues. The experience is not repeated because target e-journalism through social network for the next PIR period. The achievement level of the indicator can be estimated at 20%. * Activities with high schools competition are possible during either in the 1st quarter or in the 4th quarter of the year. Unfortunately, the 1st quarter 2015 has been devoted to electoral activities. So, high school competition is not yet conducted. Although this activity does not start, informal contacts are taken with the National TV channel office and the education authorities to identify an appropriate approach to be used. The achievement level of the indicator can be estimated at 20%. * The baseline awareness is not reported. Nonetheless, the assessment on prefectures’ capacities to implement Rio conventions has delivered similar results. Furthermore, the survey on the public awareness of Rio conventions carried out provides baseline data. The achievement level of the indicator can be estimated at 90%. * The project web site creation delayed due to a technical problem on the ministry’s web site which is supposed to be used as main site. But the recruitment process of a national expert is in progress. Regarding the above the performance in the output is estimated at 20%.
